body:
Thanks for the issue and for the feedback on the APIs. Currently it should be possible to create those learning curves with multiple calls to the `mlflow.log_metric` API and the [get-metrics-history](https://mlflow.org/docs/latest/rest_api.html#get-metrics-history) API. Moreover, the graphs produced in the UI should graph all values recorded with the `mlflow.log_metric` API.

That being said, currently it is impossible to control the x-value since each call to `log_metric` records only the timestamp at which it was recorded, the metric key, and the metric value. That means it is also impossible to update metric values already recorded.

If being able to control the x-axis or to update values already recorded is important, please let us know!

Just to add onto what Andrew said, you can also see curves of the metrics in the MLflow UI by clicking the metric name on either a Run's individual page or the Compare page between multiple runs. Hopefully that helps. It does look like there's no get-metrics-history in Python though so we need to expose that.

Thanks @andrewmchen and @mateiz for the prompt responses, much appreciated! I wasn't aware that the metrics were time-stamped and I'd be able to click on them to see history, that's cool! It'd be nice to log the x-value as well to see how validation metrics change over epochs/steps similar to how comet.ml does it: https://www.comet.ml/docs/python-sdk/Experiment/#experimentlog_metric or https://www.comet.ml/docs/python-sdk/Experiment/#experimentlog_epoch_end

Thank you @andrewmchen and @mateiz. I would like to be able to select and visualise several metrics in the curves pages for a run. Now, I can only select one. For example, I would like to plot on the same graph the validation and the training accuracy.
@cyril-p that makes sense! We need to figure out how the user interface for that would look but it's a good idea.

Yes please, to both x-axis control and plotting several metric together! :-)

How about making an interactive graph with plot-activating-legend under the heading metrics (this is a standard feature of plotly, see for example the second graph [here](https://plot.ly/python/create-online-dashboard/#choose-plots))? This way the metrics plot doesn't get burried so deeply and the user is free to select whatever is of relevance. It would require x-axis control, to make sure things get aligned. Y-axis scaling could be automatic (would work in many cases, but wil lead to terrible plots when two metrics of different order of magnitude are plotted together) or by adding an extra axis when required (even more awesome). 

Recharts doesn't support this out of the box, but from [this](https://github.com/recharts/recharts/issues/590) I gather it isn't entirely hopeless either.

Hi all! Great effort, many thanks to the team! I think this feature is one of the fundamental features one has to use in any ML project - logging metrics. One can use tensorboard in the meantime (as illustrated in the pytorch example), but it would be much better to have everything integrated in one place (I guess that's the goal here). 
Is there a plan to add more functionality like the one of Tensorboard?
A nice alternative would be to directly integrate/fork something like [tensorboardX](https://github.com/lanpa/tensorboardX) into mlflow . This would minimize the dependencies and the development effort - no need to rewrite something that already exists and works well.
I just want to chime in. Being able to explicitly log per epoch is a crucial feature. I actually routinely log parameters per epoch (changing learning rate and momentum, anybody?).
I am curious to know. the reason you can plot a metric if you cannot have multiple values?
We're actually hoping to add this in the API soon. @smurching is working on a design.

@smurching, @mateiz -- as part of the design it might be worth considering also whether artifacts could be attached to a given epoch. It would make sense to tie together, e.g., a serialized model, example generated images, and the metrics for an epoch so that they could be explored and retrieved in a coherent way.
